item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:22, topic:353254”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=449568.msg3304011#msg3304011 date=1281533864]
Has anyone tried whether you need to include all directories for compiling?
[/quote]No one needs to try, you don’t need to include anything that is called from classes in your original compiled directory.
http://download-llnw.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/windows/javac.html[/quote]
:o Thanks for that link, I’m reading it.

Read full topic

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Primadude, post:19, topic:353254”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=449568.msg3302328#msg3302328 date=1281395619]
Also, when you package, you usually want to create an instance of all the classes you will be using in either a main engine, or in each class that will use the packaged class.
[/quote]

You’ll only need to create an instance if you want to keep getting/setting the same data (Only needed if the data doesn’t have the static modifier).[/quote]Usually in a server that’s what you do; you don’t keep creating new instances of classes (except for entities)

Read full topic

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

Davidi2:

Also, when you package, you usually want to create an instance of all the classes you will be using in either a main engine, or in each class that will use the packaged class.

You’ll only need to create an instance if you want to keep getting/setting the same data (Only needed if the data doesn’t have the static modifier).

Read full topic

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Also, when you package, you usually want to create an instance of all the classes you will be using in either a main engine, or in each class that will use the packaged class. Obviously if you only call the class once (like your example) you don’t need to, but otherwise it’s a good idea.[quote=“Rixxx, post:16, topic:353254”][quote author=deathschaos9 link=topic=449568.msg3300669#msg3300669 date=1281287391]

My servers packaged and I’ve always used that compiler.

Hmm… that compiler would only be able to compile the classes in the src folder, no?

As well as all the sub-folders.
[/quote]
I never knew that.[/quote]I thought that it will compile all of the classes that it calls/imports as well, not the sub folders. Someone can correct me on this, but for example, if you have this setup:

Main -> Example1.java, Example2.java -> Example3.java

and Example 3 calls example1, and imports example2, you could javac ./Main/Example3.java and it will compile the other files as well. But say it doesn’t call or import either of the others, it wont compile the others.

Read full topic

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

[quote=“deathschaos9, post:10, topic:353254”]Couldn’t you just use

javac -d bin/ src/*.java

rather than

javac-d bin/src src/com/server/Server.java src/com/server/io/*.java src/com/server/misc/*.java src/com/server/model/item/*.java src/com/server/model/npc/*.java src/com/server/model/player/*.java src/com/server/model/player/io/*.java src/com/server/model/player/save/*.java

[/quote]

Couldn’t you just use…

An IDE?

Seriously, I don’t get why people don’t use IDE’s. Yeah, they’re hard to understand at first, however once you’re used to them they make programming over 9000 times easier…

Read full topic

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“JaydenD12, post:7, topic:353254”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=449568.msg3298916#msg3298916 date=1281143144]

This is good, but this isn’t a section for Java tutorials, its for server tutorials.

It’s a tutorial relevant directly to RuneScape 2 Private Servers and nothing else.

I will demonstrate how it could be used for RSPS.

Although this tutorial isn’t directly related to RSPS it can be very helpful. It does have use in RSPS development so I see no problem with it staying.

Perhaps revising your tutorial and using an RSPS as an example would be better Rixxx.

I will because I realized there I completely forgot about the wL stuff I talked about.

Thanks, you helped me with packaging. I wasn’t really sure on how to package correctly.
[/quote]Glad I helped.

Why the fuck do people still manually package their servers, it’s fucking retarded. With eclipse IDE you can package an entire server within 5 minutes.

Also;

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/package/index.html

IMO, a majority of newer MoparScapers has little knowledge of what an IDE is and is still programming Java in Notepad. This would be a good start for them. The link you provided was already there but thanks for sharing again.

I don’t recall it being there when I first replied to the topic.[/quote]
Oh, mine was different. http://download-llnw.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/package/index.html

Read full topic

This is good, but this isn’t a section for Java tutorials, its for server tutorials.

item.title: Packaging
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[center][size=99pt]hello,[/size][/center]
Introduction
Many people still have unorganized winterLove-based servers with them. So let’s package them into different directories according (preferably) the category they should belong to.

Packaging
How do we do it? Let’s look at an example below.

[code=Java]package packaging;

public class PackageExample {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	System.out.println("I'm packaged.");
}

}[/code]

Once you have created that class, save it under a folder named [tt]packaging[/tt] and nothing else or you will be returned with a [tt]NoClassDefFoundError[/tt] error if you try to run by using [tt]java PackageExample[/tt] instead of [tt]java packaging.PackageExample[/tt] (the one which you should use).

Additionally, you could have a package in another (also known as sub-packaging), as typed out below.

[code=java]package packaging.random;

public class RixxxRocks {

public static void derp() {
	System.out.println("I'm a derp.");
}

}[/code]

Using a package
Now it’s time to learn how to use a package! You followed the tutorial, right…? There are actually 2 ways to use a package but I shall teach you only one - importing. When you use the [tt]import[/tt] keyword, you can call classes only with the public modifier within the package. Let’s try using the import method! Important: You cannot import sub-packages by just importing a package!

[code=java]package packaging;

import packaging.random.RixxxRocks; //import just the RixxxRocks class
import packaging.random.*; //import all the public classes in the random library

public class PackageExample {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
            System.out.println("I'm packaged.");
	RixxxRocks.derp();
    }

}[/code]

The output would read:

I'm packaged. I'm a derp.

More
Read up more on packaging here or here. Always remember to name classes with a capital letter for its first letter of each word! A package should always be in lower cases.

Application (test)
Now that you’ve learnt packaging, it’s time to apply it on a server. Download this source: Cleaned WinterLove by jmood128. I’m choosing it because it’s the cleanest one around.

Folder contents of the [tt]src[/tt] folder:

[ul][li]Client.java[/li]
[li]Config.java[/li]
[li]Cryption.java[/li]
[li]GarbageCleaner.java[/li]
[li]IOClient.java[/li]
[li]IOHostList.java[/li]
[li]IOThread.java[/li]
[li]Item.java[/li]
[li]LoadConfigFile.java[/li]
[li]Misc.java[/li]
[li]NPC.java[/li]
[li]NPCHandler.java[/li]
[li]NPCList.java[/li]
[li]NpcThread.java[/li]
[li]Player.java[/li]
[li]PlayerHandler.java[/li]
[li]Saver.java[/li]
[li]Server.java[/li]
[li]Stream.java[/li][/ul]

To test whether you have really learned anything, package that server (and of course import the used classes) into this:

2vtqn0z.jpg760×507

Compile it with this new batch file (alternatively, you can use ANT but this batch file saves the hassle):

@echo off title Compiling... javac.exe -d bin/src src/com/server/Server.java src/com/server/io/*.java src/com/server/misc/*.java src/com/server/model/item/*.java src/com/server/model/npc/*.java src/com/server/model/player/*.java src/com/server/model/player/io/*.java src/com/server/model/player/save/*.java pause echo Done cls Build.bat

and run it with this:

@echo off title Cleaned WinterLove cd bin/src java Server pause

If you can compile and run without any errors, congratulations, you have passed this test! Now you can proceed to package your own server - but remember, always make a backup before doing so! I cannot emphasize how important it is to make a backup.

Read full topic
